Definition: Accelerate adaptation to the adversary by e.g. analyzing past moves of an adversary and developing new tactics
Example 1: A military officer analyzes the moves of the enemy and continuously learns lessons for future operations
Example 2: Firms in a highly competitive market collects information on its competitors and adjusts its prices and strategy

Definition: Lengthen or shorten the planning horizon to match the ability to forecast
Example 1: Financial advisor recommends holding stocks for at least several year due to volatility
Example 2: Manager uses quarterly rather than annual goals due to uncertainty about long-term strategy

Definition: Make the arsenal of resources as large as possible
Example 1: A general builds as large an army as possible to prepare for uncertain enemy size
Example 2: An investor raises as much funds as possible to manage unexpected costs and delays
Example 3: A logistics officer ahead of a military operation tries to build up the stores of all needed parts and supplies to the maximal extent possible
Related strategies and aliases: Factor of safety - but here we don't even know the baseline "minimum" and the strategy is to amass "as much as possible"
Notes: macro strategy related to Factor of Safety, Contingency planning

Definition: seek out anomalous readings and trigger alerts
Example 1: A software developer monitors for errors and their context in a new mobile app, and then investigates the causes of emerging errors
Example 2: A counterintelligence officer investigates anomalous access to sensitive data in order to detect potential espionage
Notes: Often anomaly is detected using software, but this is because software is very useful across different domains

Definition: Invest in capability that can neutralize an opponent's possible strength
Example 1: Xerxes builds a bride that allows him to send an army to Greece without fear of the Greek navy
Example 2: Militarily weak states acquire nuclear weapons

Definition: A physical system that automatically responds to impacting events by containing the damage
Example 1: A building's fire suppression system automatically floods affected floors to contain the fire
Example 2: Upon detecting a current anomaly, the power grid shuts down affected regions in order to protect the rest of the system
Example 3: A computer network protocol is designed to detect incorrect routes and reroute packets around them

Definition: Conduct research into the phenomenon trying to better understand its sources and dynamics
Example 1: Gov planners fund research into asteroid formation to understand planetary impact risks
Example 2: A hedge fund conducts research into how bank failures would affect different sectors of the economy

Definition: use a mixture of new and old solutions in order to provide a fallback if the new solutions fail
Example 1: A cloud engineer uses multiple versions of a software in the cloud to allow failures to fall back to a proven version
Example 2: A factory manager introduces a new better assembly line but does not immediately shut down the old line in case of unexpected problems
Notes: The idea is in the style of post-release testing but is done later in the development cycle and involves keeping an old but tested solution around longer as a backup

Definition: When playing against a risk-averse opponent, bluff
Example 1: A poker player makes a high bet in order to cause his risk-averse opponent to fold
Example 2: A statesman uses a show of force to impress readiness to go to war

Definition: Use a proxy to detect hazards or bound the potential effect of hazards
Example 1: a software firm deploys a software update to part of its userbase to reduce the effect of errors
Example 2: A miner uses a bird to detect likely depletion of oxygen or poison in the air
Notes: there are two versions: classic canary bird and canary deployment

Definition: Prevent a conflict from escaling to higher or less predictible levels
Example 1: Nuclear powers establish a Red Phone to prevent incidents from sparking a conflict
Example 2: Criminal bosses meet to prevent escalation of street battles

Definition: Reduce the number of independent agents or degrees of freedom to make it more predictable or manageable
Example 1: GH Bush urged Ukraine to remain in the USSR to reduce the risk of another government holding nuclear weapons
Example 2: Automotive engineer designs a car using fewer system delivered by a smaller number of Tier 1 suppliers
Notes: consolidation deliberately removes internal freedoms in the system unlike coordination that reduces it often temporarily

Definition: The ability of users to challenge the output with a third party, thus prevent gross errors
Example 1: Court system allows decisions to be appealed and overturned by a superior court
Example 2: Online retailer allows customer to contact a service center about errors in their automatic bills

Definition: Establishing thorough plans, procedures, and technical measures that can enable a system to be recovered as quickly and effectively as possible following a service disruption
Example 1: An army general develops different defense plans for different enemy attack scenarios
Example 2: An engineer programming an industrial PLC system develops a response plan for most likely possible faults or equipment malfunction to safety stop the process

Definition: Coordinate the response of multiple actors to improve its effectiveness
Example 1: Central banks coordinate a response to liquidity shortage by jointly increasing liquidity
Example 2: An army introduces a network awareness system allowing all officers to see the battlefield in real time
Notes: Leaders can often be incredibly effective by coordinating "we will be driving on the right side" - no coercion required

Definition: Make decision following the steps of others or by following a decision algorithm
Example 1: To decide between renting vs. buying, a citizen uses an online calculator from the NY Times
Example 2: To develop a strategy for their startup, the founders use a template from business school
Example 3: A doctor uses a decision tree to find the best treatment for a given patient
Notes: Decision templates can assist others in determining what the decision maker is supposed to do, e.g. an operational plan with branch points

Definition: Minimize the damage from intelligent hazard by create false targets
Example 1: A military pilot deploys a decoy to attract anti-air missiles and deflect them from striking his plane
Example 2: An airport safety manager uses food to attract birds away from planes and scarecrews to push them out
Related strategies and aliases: decoy is a type of deflection for guided/intelligent adversaries; it might involve either attraction or sometimes repulsion

Definition: Move the site impacted by the hazard in order to reduce the damage
Example 1: A lightning rod is added to a tower to deflect lightning strikes to the metal and away from the masonry
Example 2: Tandem armor-piercing projectiles are designed to deflect explosive armor so that the secondary charge could survive and penetrate the armor (an example of offensive deflection).
Notes: The strategy of a sacrificial part (e.g. fuse) can be seen as a subtype of this strategy
Note 2: Reducing the production time (Flyvberg) is another example

Definition: Delay the start time of the hazard in order to reduce its effect
Example 1: A government cabinet closes borders in response to an outbreak abroad to delay its entry
Example 2: A government cabinet partially restricts the sales of e-cigarettes pending more information of their potential for addiction

Definition: Delegate authority to local agents or stakeholders to select among alternatives within an overall mission
Example 1: An investor seeks a manager/executive who use insights to make investment or management decisions
Example 2: A general gives officers the authority to take local initiative to achieve their high-level goals (Mission Command)

Definition: Denying options to an adversary to reduce uncertainty about their action
Example 1: A general destroys the enemy's stockpile of missiles limiting it's ability for long range strikes
Example 2: A tech executive pays the best engineers generously to prevent them from launching competing products

Definition: Establish the root cause of a pathology or anomaly by excluding all the alternatives
Example 1: Doctor establishes a diagnosis by removing other possibilities
Example 2: A detective identifies a suspect by finding an alibi for other suspects

Definition: Disperse a critical resource to multiple sites in order to prevent a single event from causing total loss
Example 1: A general disperses his ammunition to multiple sites to prevent their loss to a single enemy attack
Example 2: An investor places his funds in multiple banks to prevent a single banking failure from destroying his wealth
Example 3: A cloud engineer replicates the data to multiple data centers to prevent data loss
Notes: In physical goods, the material is physically divided. For information or virtual goods, the dispersion involves replication.

Definition: Predict and detect possible hazardous events and help minimize their devastating impact
Example 1: Gov intelligence service warns of an attack allowing the military to be mobilized
Example 2: Meteorogist reviews the track of hurricanes and alerts if it will approach land

Definition: Reduce uncertainty about a plan or system but eliminating variables affecting its operation or reducing their variability
Example 1: Software developer gives users only a limited number of options to control and the rest are fixed or accessible to power users only
Example 2: A car factory manager reduces uncertainty about daily output by holding an inventory of components with variable supply
Related strategies and aliases: Managerial assumptions is somewhat the organizational version of this strategy
Notes: Related to firewalling but here certain parts of the system or its inputs are filtered while allowing others to be unmodified

Definition: Determine the type of an event and reduce uncertainty about its perpetrators, nature and consequences
Example 1: A nuclear forensics team specializes on finding the likely maker of nuclear materials used in an explosion
Example 2: A cyber forensics teams helps reduce uncertainty about the actor responsible for attacks

Definition: Find risks by exploring events and their consequences to the system
Example 1: Medical engineers use ETA to analyze the safety of the defibrillator device
Example 2: It is used to evaluate the reliability analysis of power system and failure outcomes

Definition: An approach to design and development that focuses on creating systems that can be easily changed and adapted over time
Example 1: A system architect stores data in a more portable format to ensure it can be easily retrieved in the future
Example 2: An engineer designs a factory to make it easy to add new production lines if the demand grows
Example 3: Due to concerns about unplanned expenditures, a financial officer places cash only in highly liquid bonds
Notes: This is typical for problems with multiple decision steps (design step, re-design step)
Note 2: This subsumes two ideas: simple versatility (e.g. extra production capacity, related to real options) and "meta-versatility" i.e. architecture designed to be flexible (e.g. using easy-to-scale architecture)

Definition: Systematically evaluate all action alternatives
Example 1: A company opening a new office evaluates all properties currently on the market assuming normal trends for costs and benefits
Example 2: A firm looking for a vendor for laptops evaluates all vendors on the market
Notes: unlike scenario planning, this involves primarily benefits
Note 2: Included in RDOT when it helps evaluate alternatives

Definition: Perform detailed analysis of options involving data collection, modeling and other means
Example 1: In evaluating a new facility for storing hazardous waste, an environment manager orders a detailed geological study to evaluate environmental impacts
Example 2: In response to rising sea levels near Florida, a government scientist develops a comprehensive model of flooding risk

Definition: Convene experts in the phenomenon and ask for their recommendation
Example 1: In determining how to turn around a failing firm, the board hires management consultants
Example 2: A court asks a forensic consultant to determine if the DNA evidence is valid
Related strategies and aliases: Delegation of a decision can be viewed as a case of expert judgement - the delegate is usually more informed or better able to negotiate

Definition: Design the system to be stronger than strictly necessary in order to make it survive unexpected events
Example 1: An engineer add a margin of safety to structures and machine to survive unexpected stresses
Example 2: A bank risk officer opens credit facilities with other banks that are larger than strictly necessary just in case extra liquidity is needed
Notes: see Flydberg on modular construction and cost

Definition: a design that in the event of a fault fails in a safe way or degrades gracefully
Example 1: An air-dropped bomb cannot be accidently detonated on the ground because its detonator is armed only once it falls
Example 2: A passively-safe reactor core cannot explode because by design when it overheats the nuclear reaction stops
Notes: Related idea: Restart reservoir - the ability of the system to go into safe mode and then go back to normal operation - common in computing, but also found in biology where some environments are reservoirs from which the species can recover from a bad season

Definition: Failure modes and effects analysis (FMEA) is a bottom-up (inductive) analysis approach to evaluate all the component failure and predict the impact of these failures
Example 1: Nuclear designers evaluate a nuclear reactor subsystems for possible failure modes and effects
Example 2: Rail engineers evaluate rail-road crossing control system (RCCS)
reference2: United States. Mil-Std-1629: (2000). Standard: Failure Mode and Effect Analysis.

Definition: A formal approach for resolving the basic causes of a given undesired event
Example 1: An aerospace engineer uses FTA to identify the likely cause of an explosion in a fuel tank
Example 2: Similarly, for exploring failures in a power plant
Notes: FTA operates backwards from a known undesirable event while ETA moves forward to possible undesired events
Note 2: Related term is Root Cause Analysis

Definition: Explore and reject actions until a solution is found that satisfies all constraints
Example 1: In ordering food at a new restaurant, a customer with a food alergy asks about different options until finding one that does not have the allergen
Example 2: In selecting a present, wife buys her husband a book about history, because he generally enjoys books about history
Notes: The strategy's core idea is to abandon the search for an optimum, and instead find something that will be meet a threshold of performance

Definition: Compartmentalize an at-risk system to prevent damage from spreading, or create firebreaks in an existing system
Example 1: A forest manager builds roads in a forest to create firebreaks
Example 2: A ship is designed in water-tight bulkheads so that any flood, fire or hazard could be contained within a single compartment and prevent catastrophic effects
Related strategies and aliases: related to a lifeboat and sacrificial part, except that a lifeboat is a purpose-built escape solution and generally not able to protect the bulk of the system; sacrificial part is usually sacrificed rather than withstands

Definition: Use game theory to analyze actions and risk of actions of other players
Example 1: A diplomat plans a strategy of moves and offer in order to achieve a favoriable settlement
Example 2: A chain of car gas stations uses game-theoretic analysis to set prices in the face of competition from other chains

Definition: Collect data about the unknown
Example 1: In developing his attack plan, a military commander conducts detailed reconnaissance of the enemy
Example 2: A software vendor conducts market research ahead of developing a new product
Example 3: An engineers uses a detailed model to collect data and estimate the probability of anomalous events

Definition: Increase the number of favorable outcomes by increasing the number of trials
Example 1: An e-commerce site grows the number of followers in order to ensure that enough will eventually buy
Example 2: A clinical trial enrolls a large number of participants to ensure a sufficient statistical power
Notes: Most of the example depend on the law of large numbers. The clinical trial example is also dependent on N but in a more statistical sense.

Definition: A hazard and operability study (HAZOP) is a structured and systematic examination of a planned or existing process or operation in order to find and evaluate problems that may represent risks to personnel or equipment, or prevent efficient operation
Example 1: An independent engineering team conducts a HAZOP on a proposed train station
Example 2: A chemical engineering team evaluates the operations of a plan 5 years after it was commissioned
Notes: Related: WHIPP or Walkdown Hazard Identification for Plant and Process is a hazard identification technique which can be applied to chemical plants, but with modification can be tailored for many industry types.
reference2: Redmill, F, Chudleigh, M and Catmur, J, April 1999, System Safety: HAZOP and Software HAZOP, Wiley, ISBN 0471 98280 6

Definition: Apply a heuristic on-the-spot to select a solution ignoring uncertainty
Example 1: A student selects a field of study in college based on the most inspiring course in high school, ignoring uncertainty about career outcomes
Example 2: An algorithmic trader sells half of any position once its value doubles

Definition: a scientific method that uses inductive reasoning to make predictions and then tests those predictions with experiments
Example 1: To establish the diagnosis of a patient, a doctor proceeds through differential diagnosis and workup of his patient
Example 2: A scientist that observes an unexplained reading develops a series of theoretical explanations and tests them with further experiments
Notes: Related: An intelligence officer receiving data, attempts to formulate hypotheses about the enemy's plans

Definition: Establish a unit or agency responsible for investigating incidents to drive preventative measures
Example 1: Regulators established agencies to investigate air crashes
Example 2: The CDC is responsible for investigating outbreaks of diseases and determine their causes

Definition: Establish a team dedicated to responding rapidly and effectively to hazards
Example 1: City creates a SWAT team for fast response to violent attacks
Example 2: CISO creates a cyber response unit to focus on responding to intrusions

Definition: Share the design and current state of a system with users, operators and third parties to reduce their uncertainty
Example 1: Engineers reactors operators more information about the system to help them better see and respond to faults
Example 2: New AI software for planning intentory levels provide explanations for its predictions (XAI) allowing users to determine if its predictions are caused by faulty inputs or not
Example 3: US Federal Reserve bank provide minutes of their meetings to financial markets

Definition: Rather than building the entire solution, construct the solution incrementally, adding new features to learn about risks
Example 1: A startup founder introduces a minimal viable product (MVP) to gauge demand and identify problems
Example 2: A software engineer uses Agile increments, presenting the results to stakeholders every two weeks

Definition: Use of an independent organization to review safety and risks
Example 1: Chemical manufacturer contracts with a specialist firm to review a new design for hazards
Example 2: A firm sends its accounts for audits with an independent accounting firm

Definition: Require all technology and/or operators to be certified by an organization unrelated to their employer
Example 1: Doctors are certified by medical associations
Example 2: Pilots are certified by government agencies or companies sponsored by them
Example 3: Electrical devices are certified by Underwriters Labs and others

Definition: Develop an index (a random variable) to describe the uncertain quantity in order to enable securitization, anomaly tracking etc
Example 1: A financial firm develops an index of healthcare costs in order to enable firms to hedge against future cost increases
Example 2: Scientists develop a measure of global temperatures to enable planning for climate change

Definition: Using an index of the phenomenon, estimate measures of volatility to drive the response
Example 1: Investor calculates the price volatility of a stock and compares it to his existing investments without fundamental research into its pricing
Example 2: To determine if their pandemic control strategy is working, the health department is monitoring the number of weekly cases
Example 3: A farmer decides to reduce sales of his harvest in anticipating of prices recovering to their long-term average
Related strategies and aliases: Index-building is used when the index is not yet available

Definition: Use contracts or financial instruments to indemnify against possible losses
Example 1: An investor buys options to limit to create a floor to losses on a risky stock
Example 2: A real estate investor purchases an insurance contract for any flood risks
Notes: Originally: transferable risk. Risk-based contracts such as contracts to salesmen, salary vs. hourly are all part of risk-reduction strategies but in an everyday sense - they also incentivize performance

Definition: A device or process that quickly shuts down a system
Example 1: scram a reactor
Example 2: stop a train

Definition: Condense and communicate existing knowledge to all members of the group in order to make them more effective
Example 1: A manager introduces training about cyber threats to all members of his team
Example 2: A veteran soldier shares combat experience with newly-drafted soldiers
Notes: Novel - this is very common but worth stating - a strategy often missed

Definition: Implement a subsystem that can protect human users from the disaster, or generally, prevent total loss
Example 1: A naval engineer adds lifeboats so that if the ship sinks, at least the people can survive
Example 2: An investor keeps a small amount of savings in cash in case of a catastrophic financial event

Definition: Invest in assets that benefit from increased volatility
Example 1: An investor purchases options that would rise in value of volatility increases
Example 2: At a sailboat race, the captain selects a course that experiences stronger and more variable winds to gain a chance to beat the frontrunners

Definition: Manager or commander reduces uncertainty by imposing limits or assumptions on his unit
Example 1: Engineers for the lunar lander in Apollo were told to assume that lunar surface would resemble the California desert
Example 2: A CEO orders search for new corporate acquisitions in the next fiscal year

Definition: Select between actions using estimated probability of events and their outcomes
Example 1: A manager selects an industrial machine from different vendors with different costs and failure probabilities
Example 2: A college students selects a career based on expected salary, interest and probability of success

Definition: a type of mathematical modeling that uses known physical principles to describe the behavior of a system and forecast its state
Example 1: A process engineer develops a detailed model of a factory to predict the likelihood of process disruption in the next 7 days
Example 2: A supply chain manager develops a stock-and-flow model of a supply chain in order to optimize purchases and inventory levels

Definition: Identify gaps in knowledge in order to prioritize their closure or ensure safe degradation
Example 1: A scientist finds gaps in the scientific literature
Example 2: Intelligence agency or business strategies identifies gaps in its knowledge of the enemy/competitors

Strategy for uncertainty: Minimize area or time of impact
Definition: Shape the impacting event or the threatened system to minimize the area or time of impact
Example 1: A cybersecurity officer minimizes the number of access methods to sensitive data or network to reduce the risk of a successful penetration
Example 2: An army general plans a withdrawal to occur as rapidly as possible, to reduce the risk of an enemy attack during this sensitive time window when defenses are abandoned.
Notes: related to deflect another example is the idea of blast compartment - do all dangerous work in a special hardened place

Definition: Cause the adversary to make incorrect action by creating a false impression of own action
Example 1: An officer installs decoy targets in order to cause the enemy to waste his attacks and thus protect the true assets
Example 2: A poker player uses bluffs to make the other players fold rather than risk a showdown
Notes: Not a response to uncertainty

Definition: Use independent modules in order to make the system easier to build and repair
Example 1: A software engineer designs uses the microservices archives so that the software could be easily updated
Example 2: Napoleon divides his army into independent divisions, giving the army greater agility under changing conditions on the strategic map (e.g. pursue enemy forces along independent axes)
Related strategies and aliases: Modular design is usually selected for efficiency and simplicity rather than safety (see firebreak)

Definition: Design a system to absorb or respond to threats using multiple layers of defensive barriers
Example 1: A general builds multiple lines of trenches so that in event of an enemy breach he can withdraw to a new line of defense
Example 2: A stock exchange use a waterfall of pools of capital to ensure all contracts are paid in any bankruptcy events
Example 3: Business uses a three-lines of defense model to manage risks from operations
Related strategies and aliases: Related to robust design or what could be called redundant design; Sometimes called defense-in-depth; multi-echelon defense
Notes: Another example is the swiss cheese model of pandemic preparedness

Definition: Require all new operators to be evaluated by an experienced co-pilot
Example 1: Regulators allow pilots to fly only after completing a checkride with an instructor
Example 2: A hospital manager only allows residents to prescribe after completing 6 months are a hospital under supervision

Definition: an organizational unit or process whose role is collect and priority opportunities for gains
Example 1: military intelligence reports gaps in enemy readiness that could be exploited
Example 2: an executive establishes a process to collect and prioritize new ideas
Example 3: the market intelligence unit identifies market opportunities for the business

Definition: Decide by maximizing the total welfare
Example 1: An aircrew scheduling algorithm maximizes the total utility over all the crew members weighted by rank
Example 2: An algorithm allocates antivirals to hospitals to maximize the total value but accounting for fairness

Definition: Prevent damage from hazards by establishing a perimeter and detect threats as soon as they reach the perimeter
Example 1: A wilderness leader establishes a fence against wild animals around his camp connected to an alarm system
Example 2: new cybersecurity software uses endpoint detection and response to detect threats on devices connected to the network
Related strategies and aliases: early warning (but at the point of contact)
Notes: not sure if this is a solution for uncertainty

Definition: Collect data from experts and stakeholders and select action supported by a qualified majority, to reduce the risk of a mistake
Example 1: A venture capital firm's investment committee vote on investing in a new firm
Example 2: A politician meets with constituents and selects which policy he will support

Definition: Systematically adjust a portfolio of items to avoid excessive risk
Example 1: An investor maximizes returns by partially selling appreciated assets while buying assets that decline in value
Example 2: A general invests more resources in an offensive thrust that made more progress

Definition: evaluate the system after its release to detect unexpected or dangerous behaviors
Example 1: A car maker monitors any fatal accidents on a new car model to detect any faulty components
Example 2: A pharmaceutical is monitored after marketing in phase 4 studies to observe any potentially dangerous side effects not caught in its development

Definition: evaluate the system before its deployment to detect unexpected or dangerous behaviors
Example 1: A software engineer implements automatic testing to detect errors
Example 2: A pharmaceutical is tested in a clinical trial to determine if it has unacceptable side effects

Definition: Invest in preventing the worst case outcome regardless of its probability
Example 1: A government regulator bans a new product to prevent the possibility of it becoming a large health problem
Example 2: A dominant firm acquires even the smallest competitor firms to prevent the possibility of any one becoming a serious challenger

Definition: Develop a probabilistic model of the risks and develop strategies to mitigate it efficiently
Example 1: A risk officer in a bank develop a model of financial risks and build a risk management strategy
Example 2: Nuclear reactor engineers identify the risk of different events and developing solutions to reduce them

Definition: Build a simple version of a complex solution in order to reduce risks and complexity, then progress to a more sophisticated version (or potentially a series thereof)
Example 1: An architect uses a physical model to evaluate the proposed structure for light and walkability
Example 2: An aeronautical engineer builds and tests a new risky propulsion technology in order to ultimately use it in missions
Notes: Flyvberg's discussion of separating a large project into repeatable modules. Often simplification can be done purely for research (this is a separate strategy under research) - here simplification is used to reduce risk. Conscious risk reduction in spiral development, MVP, simulation.

Definition: Staff are trained to question anomalies rather than merely check off boxes
Example 1: Industrial equipment operators are trained to take action if they see anomalous signs
Example 2: Riders in public transit are trained to contact authorities if they see suspecious objects

Definition: Deliberately randomize actions in order to avoid being anticipated by an adversary
Example 1: A security officer randomly selects a route to transport a VIP at risk of assassination
Example 2: A general deliberately makes unpredictable moves in order to keep the enemy off balance and unable to carry its own surprises
Notes: Randomization can be both a response to uncertainty and a strategy to win using uncertainty

Definition: If unable to prevent adverse events, develop the capability to detect them rapidly in order to respond as quickly as possible and reduce ultimate damage
Example 1: Software rapidly detects cyber-penetrations into the network to minimize the number of systems affected
Example 2: Epidemiologists sequence the genomes of COVID-19 samples in order to detect the emergence of dangerous new variants and implement timely containment measures

Definition: Invest resources in obtaining a positive risk
Example 1: An executive invests in developing a prototype product for a small but growing market
Example 2: A transportation planner asks for a new airport able to accomodate 100% growth in air traffic
Example 3: An investor purchases a call option for a promising stock (an example of a financial real option)

Definition: Discover risks by establishing a unit responsible for ethically attacking the system
Example 1: An information officer hires a red team to attempt to penetrate his company
Example 2: A red team in a military tabletop exercise attempts to play the enemy's side and find weaknesses in the own side's plans

Definition: Set limitations on risky activities in order to reduce risk
Example 1: A government regulator bans a new product to prevent the possibility of it becoming a large health problem
Example 2: A corporating bans work with certain clients to reduce risk to its reputation

Definition: Establish processes and guidelines for doing risky activities in order to prevent accidents and other unwanted outcomes
Example 1: Military planners require multiple officers to approve the launch of a nuclear weapon to prevent accidental or malicious launch
Example 2: A software engineering manager requires all changes of the live system to go through an approval process, to reduce the risk of breaking changes

Definition: Iteratively try different actions (manually or algorithmically), measure the outcomes and optimize the actions
Example 1: A trading algorithm examines the rewards from different trading rules and adjust them to improve their profitability
Example 2: An online store uses A/B testing to select the optimal design - users see either version A or B of the site, until it's clear which version has a higher conversion rate
Notes: Maybe more general - sequential decision

Definition: System designed to absorb, respond to, and recover from disasters and adapt to new conditions
Example 1: A community planner develops a response plan for a community at risk of hurricanes
Example 2: An electrical engineer designs a power plant develops special control program for weather emergencies allowing the plant to quickly shut down and then quickly restart

Definition: A technique for risk management that involves building a grid of undesirable events as rows and corresponding controls that could mitigate them
Example 1: A technology manager uses RACM to identify cyberattacks and plan controls
Example 2: A corporate auditor builds a RACM for risks to the organization and controls

Definition: Balance investments between different risks and opportunities to improve overall risk
Example 1: An investment manager builds a portfolio of investments to consider their risk and returns as well as their correlations
Example 2: A student applies to multiple colleges - some selective and some not selective - to maximize his outcome
Example 3: Ecosystems use a porfolio in a variety of settings

Definition: Grow by either producing a large number of offsprings or few highly-capable ones
Example 1: A computer science student studies 5 different programming languages in order to ensure at least one successful job placement
Example 2: A CEO focuses the entire product development budget in one major initiative

Definition: Evaluate a solution and its feasibility against uncertainty in parameters of the problem
Example 1: Chemical engineers evaluated their solution's robustness by evaluating the effect of parameters
Example 2: Any other application of linear programming

Definition: Design where functions and flows that are critical to system operation are protected through the sacrifice of less critical functions and flow exports
Example 1: An electrical engineer installs a fuse that will burn if there is a high current protecting the system behind it
Example 2: A lawyer creates a legal entity (e.g. corporation or subsidiary) that bears risks to shield its owners from legal or financial risks

Definition: Create an organization culture that advances hazard prevention, investigation and mitigation
Example 1: A construction site manager increases safety culture by paying workers to improve site safety
Example 2: A medical center does not penalize for reporting of mistakes

Definition: Limit the operation of system to narrow domain of environments, users or inputs to mitigate unexpected behaviors or dangerous inputs
Example 1: Operate a new AI system only on well-tested data
Example 2: Manager allow only well-trained workers to operate a forklift
Example 3: Parents don't let kids play with matches to prevent fires

Definition: Disarming mechanism - programmed self-disablement, self-disarmament or self-destruction
Example 1: Anti-personel mine has a timer that disables it to prevent accidental harm to own forces or non-combatants
Example 2: Self-driving vehicle automatically parks if it finds itself in a situation it can't manage

Definition: Use simple solutions, designs and plans
Example 1: Japanese attacks often failed because of poor timing of multiple strike forces
Example 2: Mechanical engineer reduces the number of components in the system
Example 3: A software engineer uses APIs to reduce the complexity and risk of individual interfaces
Notes: is this configurational org or system? the idea is the same in both. it's even a meta strategy since it advises on any other strategy

Definition: System that interdicts impacting events before their arrival
Example 1: An air defense system fires interceptors to destroy attacking vehicles
Example 2: Upon detection of a denial of service attack, CISO blocks traffic from select IP addresses and networks

Definition: Define standard operating procedures or plans for routine and exceptional situations
Example 1: A plant engineers writes a manual for performing maintenance
Example 2: An air traffic control officer writes procedures for handling emergency calls
Example 3: A medical administrator writes standard operating procedures for managing certain emergency

Definition: Develop models of past data (e.g. average and outlier) in order to estimate the likelihood and risk of hazardous events
Example 1: A bank's risk officer develops a model of large price movements based on historical data
Example 2: An epidemiologist rolls out a public advisory for an influenza emergency once the number of monthly cases doubles from average month

Definition: Apply statistical modeling to monitor and control the quality of a production process
Example 1: An industrial engineer uses SPC to prevent defects in car parts
Example 2: Similar, in aerospace engineering

Definition: Optimize system design or operation by exploring different solutions particularly when preparing to uncertainty
Example 1: A nuclear engineer uses stochastic optimization to optimize the design of a reactor for performance and safety
Example 2: A facilitary planner uses a genetic algorithm to improve the location of supply facilities
Notes: Reinforcement learning in our usage involves real-world testing rather than computational optimization

Definition: Enable new strategies in future decision points
Example 1: A government planner invests in basic research in order to enable better cyber-response technologies
Example 2: A cyber researcher tests experimental algorithms to detect intrusion
Example 3: A financial firm develops an index enabling new futures trading
Notes: research and development is merely one version of enablement
reference1: Existing literature is concerned with narrow types of enablement such as R&D or the psychology of discounting https://doi.org/10.1002/mde.2548 https://doi.org/10.1002/sys.10051

Definition: Reduce the risk of failure by finding and strengthening the weakest component
Example 1: An electrical engineer strengthens a circruit by strengthening the weakest component
Example 2: A road planner reduces congestion by increasing throughput in the most congested component

Definition: Divide responsibilities in clear defined roles to reduce uncertainty about areas of responsibility and accountability
Example 1: An executive assigns his managers to well-defined individual swim lanes to avoid possible conflicts

Definition: Using a model develop a description of the system its environment in order to improve its design
Example 1: A supply chain manager develops a stock-and-flow model of a supply chain in order to optimize purchases and inventory levels
Example 2: A nuclear reactor engineer stochastically simulates the flow of coolant in the reactor using software, and determines the risk of heat damaging reactor components

Definition: Improve the odds of favoriable outcomes by repeating trials
Example 1: A hiring manager interviews a large number of candidates to find one real star
Example 2: A job applicant sends out his resume to many different positions to ensure he lands one
Example 3: A particle physicist repeats an experiment multiple times in order to observe one special particle event
